REMUNERATION FOR PUBLICATION MEMBERS
A letter to the editor of the NEWS-LETTER published in this issue
objects to the recently announced plan for remunerating members
of staffs of undergraduate publications on the grounds, chiefly,
that the move inevitably will bring about distasteful "professionalism." He draws an analogy between athletic teams and publications, pointing out that if members of a football team were to
- receive cash for their efforts, there would be no end to the criticism that would follow.
Before advancing any other arguments, we wish to call attention to the fact that, whereas this analogy seems, superficially, to
be well drawn, closer inspection shows that it is really not so
strong. In the first place, the actual length of the season during
which the men participate in the work is entirely different; members of an athletic team practice for three months, at the most;
members of a publication staff give up from two to four afternoons a week throughout the year. A second difference—one
which, although it sounds extremely childish,is actually based upon
adult human nature—is that members of athletic teams receive a
very considerable reward in the form of "glory" and "publicity."
Superficial as such rewards may appear to be, they have proved
to be great incentives to hard work during an athletic "season."
Now members of publications bask in none of this sunshine; they
cannot look forward to the day when the season is over and they
can break training and take it easy. Their work goes on steadily
for eight months. Moreover, the small number of available men
does not permit staff members to take holidays every other week,
for "copy" must be written.
It is only natural, therefore, when a man has worked on a publication for two or three years, and has not attained a position on the
board which carries with it a vast amount of prestige, his natural
inclination is to quit. And quit he usually does, doing great harm
to the publication. We realize full well that ideally it is fine to
have men work every week for three or four years for pure fun
and through pure "spirit," but, after all, human nature is unfortunately human nature. Giving these men an additional incentive
will result in a great improvement in the quality and quantity of
work that they will do for the publication.
There are cases which we can quote of men who have been
forced to resign position on the NEWS-LETTER because they needed
the time for some outside work which would be remunerative. Is
it not far better to have such men carry on? It is a well-known
fact that if an athlete is in need of funds he can nearly always find
sinecures to supply them. In the case of publications, which can
be, comparatively, as profitable undertakings as larger newspapers,
we see no reason why the men who give up much valuable time
should not be allowed to realize on their efforts.
The plan is not original at Hopkins. Princeton, for example,
has been remurerating members of publications for over eighteen
years. The members of all college dailies and a majority of semiweeklies, as well as most comics, have employed similar plans for
a number of years. The idea has received the approval here of
such men as Dean Ames, Dr. Wight, Mr. S. Page Nelson, and the
entire faculty committee on student affairs.
We hope that the feeling expressed in the letter in the "Mailbag"
does not represent widespread opinion, for we feel that, under the
conditions mentioned, there is nothing unfair or unduly "professionalistic" in the plan. It is merely a means to accomplish two
ends; first, to improve the quality of the publications by affording
keener competition, and second, to afford an additional reward for
those men to whom great quantities of glory does not accrue.

ORPHEUS AND EURYDICE
Gray. Silvery gray. Throughout the day the color had not
changed, and still the silver unrelenting rain came down. In his
doorway Orpheus stood, strumming still his omnipresent lyre, but
careless now, and without fire, were all his idle strokes. In his
longings for tonight he had painted many dreams, sung the beauty
of Eurydice, touched in his sleep the gleaming ivory of her arm,
seen clear her profile on the emptiness of night, and smelled
Spring's fragrance in her silken hair. These had been his visions
of tonight—and now—was it the taint of sorrow on the rain-swept
air, or some foresight of ill, or was it but the flatness of achieved
desire? For the dead color of the pallid ghostly landscape had
seeped like a dye into his very soul, and he could think of Eurydice
without the faintest tremor of his heart, without the slightest
aching in his arms . . . The unresponsive lyre refused to echo
the monotony of the swishing downpour. So with a shrug of
exasperation he turned and entered the house.

someone's advice, he frequented the
Levering Hall at the old location of

seeming to be an ellipse when
viewed across a table.

thing was a mistake, and the supposed initiate was only the finder
of a lost fraternity pin. No, fraternities and brothers have not after all revolutionized their standards!

REMUNERATION FOR PUBLICATION MEMBERS
A letter to the editor of the NEWS-LETTER published in this issue
objects to the recently announced plan for remunerating members
of staffs of undergraduate publications on the grounds, chiefly,
that the move inevitably will bring about distasteful "professionalism." He draws an analogy between athletic teams and publications, pointing out that if members of a football team were to
- receive cash for their efforts, there would be no end to the criticism that would follow.
Before advancing any other arguments, we wish to call attention to the fact that, whereas this analogy seems, superficially, to
be well drawn, closer inspection shows that it is really not so
strong. In the first place, the actual length of the season during
which the men participate in the work is entirely different; members of an athletic team practice for three months, at the most;
members of a publication staff give up from two to four afternoons a week throughout the year. A second difference—one
which, although it sounds extremely childish,is actually based upon
adult human nature—is that members of athletic teams receive a
very considerable reward in the form of "glory" and "publicity."
Superficial as such rewards may appear to be, they have proved
to be great incentives to hard work during an athletic "season."
Now members of publications bask in none of this sunshine; they
cannot look forward to the day when the season is over and they
can break training and take it easy. Their work goes on steadily
for eight months. Moreover, the small number of available men
does not permit staff members to take holidays every other week,
for "copy" must be written.
It is only natural, therefore, when a man has worked on a publication for two or three years, and has not attained a position on the
board which carries with it a vast amount of prestige, his natural
inclination is to quit. And quit he usually does, doing great harm
to the publication. We realize full well that ideally it is fine to
have men work every week for three or four years for pure fun
and through pure "spirit," but, after all, human nature is unfortunately human nature. Giving these men an additional incentive
will result in a great improvement in the quality and quantity of
work that they will do for the publication.
There are cases which we can quote of men who have been
forced to resign position on the NEWS-LETTER because they needed
the time for some outside work which would be remunerative. Is
it not far better to have such men carry on? It is a well-known
fact that if an athlete is in need of funds he can nearly always find
sinecures to supply them. In the case of publications, which can
be, comparatively, as profitable undertakings as larger newspapers,
we see no reason why the men who give up much valuable time
should not be allowed to realize on their efforts.
The plan is not original at Hopkins. Princeton, for example,
has been remurerating members of publications for over eighteen
years. The members of all college dailies and a majority of semiweeklies, as well as most comics, have employed similar plans for
a number of years. The idea has received the approval here of
such men as Dean Ames, Dr. Wight, Mr. S. Page Nelson, and the
entire faculty committee on student affairs.
We hope that the feeling expressed in the letter in the "Mailbag"
does not represent widespread opinion, for we feel that, under the
conditions mentioned, there is nothing unfair or unduly "professionalistic" in the plan. It is merely a means to accomplish two
ends; first, to improve the quality of the publications by affording
keener competition, and second, to afford an additional reward for
those men to whom great quantities of glory does not accrue.

seeming to be an ellipse when
viewed across a table.
